editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nicole Sheriko

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. div.p: Presented by the Queen's majesty's servants, at the phoenix in Drury-lane.
London, printed by E. P. for Henry Seile, and are to be sold at his shop, at the tiger's head in Fleetstreet, over-against saint Dunstan's church. 1638.

div.head: Act. i.

sp.speaker: Troylo.
sp.l: Do, do, be wilful, desperate, 'tis manly,
Build on your reputation, such a fortune
May furnish out your tables, trim your liveries,
Enrich your heirs, with purchase of a patrimony
Which shall hold out beyond the waste of riot,
Stick honours on your heraldry, with titles
As swelling and as numerous, as may likely
Grow to a pretty volume, here's eternity,
All this can reputation, marry can it,
Indeed what not?

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Such language from a gentleman
So noble in his quality as you are
Deserves in my weak judgement rather pity
Then a contempt.

sp.speaker: Troylo.
sp.l: Couldst thou consider Livio
The fashion of the times, their study, practice,
Nay, their ambitions, thou wouldst soon distinguish
Betwixt the abject lowness of a poverty,
And the applauded triumph of abundance,
though compassed by the meanest service, wherein
Shall you betray your guilt to common censure,
Waving the private charge of your opinion
By rising up to greatness, or at least
To plenty which now buys it.

sp.speaker: Livio
sp.l: Troylo-savelli,
Plays merrily on my wants,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Troylo-savelli.
Speaks to the friend he loves, to his own Livio,
Look prithee through the great Duke's court in Florence,
Number his favourites, and then examine
By what steps some chief officers in state
Have reached the heigh they stand in.

sp.speaker: Livio
sp.l: By their merits.

sp.speaker: Troylo
sp.l: Right, by their merits, well he merited
Th'intendments o'er the galleys at Leghorn,
Made grand collector of the customs there,
Who led the prince unto his wife's chastebed,
And stood himself by, in his night gown, fearing
The jest might be discovered: waste not handsome?
The lady knows not yet on't.

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Most impossible.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: He merited well to wear a robe of Chamlet,
Who trained his brother's daughter (Scarce a girl)
Into the arms of Mont-angentorato,
Whiles the young lord of Telaxton her husband.
Was packeted to France, to study courtship,
Under forsooth a colour of employment,
Employment, yea of honour,

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You're well read
In mysteries of state,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Here in Sienna.
Bold Julio de Varana lord of Camerine.
Held it no blemish to his blood and greatness,
From a plain merchant with a thousand ducats
To buy his wife, nay justify the purchase,
procured it by a dispensation
From Rome, allowed and warranted: 'twas thought
By his physicians, that she was a creature,
Agreed best with the cure of the disease,
His present new infirmity then laboured in.
Yet these are things in prospect of the world,
Advanced employed, and eminent.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: At best 'tis but a goodly pandarism.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Shrewd business.
Thou child in thrift, thou fool of honesty,
Is't a disparagement for gentlemen,
For friends of lower rank to do the offices
Of necessary kindness without see,
For one another, courtesies of course,
Mirths of society, when petty mushrooms,
Transplanted from their dunghills spread on mountains.
And pass for cedars by their servile flatteries
On great men's vices? — pander — thou'rt deceived,
The word includes preferment, 'tis a title
Of dignity, I could add somewhat more else,

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Add any thing of reason.

sp.speaker: Troylo.
sp.l: Castamela.
Thy beauteous sister like a precious tissue,
Not shaped into a garment fit for wearing,
Wants the adornments of the workman's cunning
To set the richness of the piece at view,
Though in herself all wonder. Come I'll tell thee,
Away there may be (Know I love thee Livio)
To fix this jewel in a ring of gold,
Yet lodge it in a cabinet of ivory,
White pure, unspotted ivory, put case
Livio himself shall keep the key on't?

sp.speaker: Livio
sp.l: O sir,
Create me what you please of yours, do this,
You are another nature,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Be then pliable.

sp.speaker: Troylo.
sp.l: Be then pliable
To my first rules of your advancement — see,
Octavio my good uncle, the great marquess
Of our Sienna comes as we could wish
In private — noble sir

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My bosom's secretary,
My dearest, best loved nephew.

sp.speaker: Troylo.
sp.l: We have been thirsty
In our pursuit — sir here's a gentleman
Desertful of your knowledge, and as covetous
Of entertainment from it, you shall honour
Your judgement, to intrust him to your favours,
His merits will commend it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Gladly welcome.
Your own worth is a herald to proclaim it:
For taste of your preferment, we admit you
The chief provisor of our horse.

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Your bounty
Styles me your ever servant.

sp.speaker: Troyo.
sp.l: He's our own,
Surely, nay most persuadedly — my thanks sir
Owes to this just engagement.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Slack no time
To enter on your fortunes — thou art careful
My Troylo in the study of a duty,
His name is Livio!

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Livio my good lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Again you're welcome to us, be as speedy
Dear nephew as thou'rt constant — men of parts,
Fit parts and sound are rarely to be met with,
But being met with, therefore to be cherished,
With love and with supportance, while I stand,
Livio can no way fall —
Yet once more welcome.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: An honourable liberality,
timely disposed without delay or question,
Commands a gratitude, is not this better
Than waiting three or four months at livery,
With cup and knee unto this chair of state,
And to their painted arras for a need
From goodman usher, or the formal secretary
Especially the juggler with the purse,
That pays some shares, in all a younger brother
Sometimes an elder, not well trimmed i'th head-piece,
May spend what his friends left in expectation,
Of being turned out of service for attendance
Or marry a waiting woman, and be damned for't
To open laughter, (And what's worth) old beggary,
What thinks my Livio of this rise at first?
Is't not miraculous.

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: It seems the bargain,
Was driven before between ye.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: 'Twas, and nothing
Could void it, but the peevish resolution
Of your dissent from goodness, as you call it,
A thin, a threadbare honesty, a virtue
Without a living to't.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I must resolve
To turn my sister whore, speak a homeword,
For my old bachelor — lord, so, is't not so?
A trifle in respect of present means,
Here's all —

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Be yet more confident, the slavery
Of such an abject office, shall not tempt
The freedom of my spirit, stand ingenious
To thine own fate, and we will practise wisely
Without the charge of scandal.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: May it prove so.

div.stage: Enter Secco with a casting-bottle, sprinkling his hat and face, and a little looking glass at his girdle, setting his countenance.

sp.speaker: Secco.
sp.p: Admirable incomparably admirable! to be the minion, the darling, the delight of love, 'tis a very tickling to the marrow, a kissing i'th blood, a bosoming the ecstasy, the rapture of virginity, soul and paradise of perfection — ah — pity of generation Secco, there are no more such men.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O yes, if any man, woman, or beast, have found, stolen, or taken up a fine, very fine male barber, of the age of above or under eighteen more or less.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Spadone, hold, what's the noise?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Umh — pay the crier, I have been almost lost myself in seeking you, here's a letter from —

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Whom, whom my dear Spadove, whom?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Soft and fair, and you be so brief, I'll return it whence it came, or look out a new owner, oh yes.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Low, low, what dost mean, is't from the glory of beauty, morosa the fairest fair, be gentle to me, here's a ducat, peak low prithee.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Give me one, and take tother, 'tis from the party, golden news believe it.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Honest Spadone divine Morosa.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Fairest fair, quoth 'a, so is an old rotten coddled mongrel, parcel bawd, parcel midwife, all the marks are quite out of her mouth, not the stump of a tooth left in her head, to mumble the curd of a posset — signior 'tis as I told ye, all's right,

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Right, just as thou told'st me, all's right,

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: To a very hair signior mio.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: For which sirrah Spadone, I will make thee a man, a man, dost hear? I say a man.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Thou'rt a prick-eared foist, a cittern headed gew-gaw , a knack, a snipper-snapper, twit me with the decrements of my pendants, though I am made a gelding, and like a tame buck have lost my dowsets, more a monster than a cuckold with his horns seen, yet I scorn to be jeered by any chequer, approved barbarian of ye all, make me a man, I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How now fellow, how now, roaring ripe indeed?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Indeed? Thou'rt worse, a dry shaver, a copper basand-suds-monger.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay, nay, by my mistress fair eyes I meant no such thing.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Eyes in thy belly, the reverend madam shall know how I have been used, I will blow my nose in thy casting bottle, break the teeth of thy combs, poison thy camphire balls, slice out thy towels with thine own razor, betallow thy tweezes, and urine in thy basin, make me a man?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Hold take another ducat, as I love new cloth;

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Or cast old ones.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Yes or cast old ones, I intended no injury.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Good, we are pieced again, reputation, signior, is precious.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I know it is.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Old sores would not be rubbed.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: For me never.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: The lady guardianess, the mother of the fancies, is resolved to draw with ye, in the wholesome of matrimony, suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: She writes as much, and Spadone, when we are married.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: You will to bed no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: We will revel in such variety of delights.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Do miracles and get babies.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Live so sumptuously.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: In feather and old furs.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Feed so deliciously.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: On pap and bulbeese.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Enjoy the sweetness of our years.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Eighteen and threescore with advantage,

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Tumble and wallow in abundance.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: The pure crystal puddle of pleasures.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That all the world should wonder.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: A pox on them that envy ye.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: How do the beauties (My dainty knave) live, wish, think, and dream, sirrah ha.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Fumble one with another, on the gambos of imagination between their legs, eat they do, and sleep, game, laugh, and lie down, as beauties ought to do, there's all.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Commend me to my choicest, and tell her, the minute of her appointment shall be waited on, say to her, she shall find me a man at all points.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Why, there's another quarrel, man, once more in spite of my nose.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Away Secco away, my lord calls, a' has a loose hair started from his fellows, a clip of your art is commanded.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I fly Nitido, Spadone remember me.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Trudging between an old moil, and a young calf, my numble intelligencer, what, thou fattenest apace on capon still?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Yes, crimpe, 'tis a gallant life to be an old lords pimp whiskin, but beware of the porters lodge, for carrying tales out of the school.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: What a terrible sight to a libed breech is a sow gelder?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Not so terrible as a cross tree that never grows, to a wag-halter-page.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p:
Good! witty rascal, thou'rt a satire I protest, but that the nymphs need not fear the evidence of thy mortality,
go put on a clean bib, and spin amongst the nuns, sing 'em a bawdy song, all the children thou get'st, shall be christened in wassail bowls, and turned into a college of men midwives, farewell nightmare.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Very, very well, if I die in thy debt for this crackrope) let me be buried in a coal-sack, I'll fit ye, (Apes face) look for't.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: And still the urchin would, but could not do.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Mark the end on't, and laugh at last.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tell me you cannot love me,

sp.speaker: Chast.
sp.l: You importune
Too strict a resolution, as a gentleman
Of commendable parts, and fair deserts,
In every sweet condition that becomes
A hopeful expectation, I do honour
Th'example of your youth, but sir our fortunes
Concluded on both sides in narrow bands,
Move you to construe gently my forbearance,
In argument of fit consideration.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why Castamela, I have shaped thy virtues
(Even from our childish years) into a dowry
Of richer estimation, than thy portion,
Doubled an hundred times, can equal: now
I clearly find, thy current of affection
Labours to fall into the guilt of riot,
Not the free ocean of a soft content.
You'd marry pomp and plenty, 'tis the idol
(I must confess) that creatures of the time,
Bend their devotions to, but I have fashioned
Thoughts much more excellent of you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Enjoy your own prosperity, I am resolved,
Never by any charge with me, to force
A poverty upon ye, want of love.
'tis rarely cherished with the love of want.
I'll not be your undoing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Sure some dotage
Of living stately, richly, lend a cunning
To eloquence. How is this piece of goodness
Changed to ambition? o you are most miserable
In your desires, the female curse has caught ye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fie, fie, how ill this suits.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A devil of pride,
Ranges in airy thoughts to catch a star,
Whiles ye grasp molehills.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Worse and worse I vow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But that some remnant of an honest sense,
Ebbs a full tide of blood to shame, all women
Would prostitute all honour to the luxury of ease and titles.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Romanello, know
You have forgotten the nobleness of truth,
And sixth on scandal now.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A dog, a parrot,
A monkey, a caroche, a guarded lackey,
A waiting woman with her lips sealed up,
Are pretty toys to please my mistress wanton:
So is a fiddle too, 'twill make it dance,
Or else be sick and whine.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: This is uncivil.
I am not sir your charge.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: My grief you are,
For all my services are lost and ruined.

sp.speaker: Chast.
sp.l: So is my chief opinion of your worthiness,
When such distractions tempt ye, you would prove
A cruel lord, who dare, being yet a servant,
As you profess, to bait my best respects
Of duty to your welfare, 'tis madness
I have not oft observed, possess your freedom.
You have no right in me, let this suffice:
I wish your joys much comfort.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Sister, look ye,
How by a new creation off my tailors,
I've shaken off old mortality, the rags
Of home spun gentry (Prithee sister mark it)
Are cast by, and I now appear in fashion
Unto men, and received, observe me sister,
The consequence concerns you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: True good brother,
For my well doing must consist in yours.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Here's Romanello, a fine tempered gallant,
Of decent carriage, of indifferent means,
Considering that his sister, new hoist up,
From a lost merchant's warehouse, to the titles
Of a great lords-bed, may supply his wants
Not sunk in his acquaintance, for a scholar
Able enough, and one who may subsist
Without the help of friends, provided always,
He fly not upon wedlock without certainty
Of an advancement, else a bachelor
May thrive by observation on a little.
As single life's no burden, but to draw
In yokes is chargeable, and will require
A double maintenance, why I can live
Without a wife, and purchase.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is't a mystery?
You've lately found out Livio, or a cunning
Concealed, till now for wonder?

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Pish, believe it,
Endeavours and an active brain, are better
Than patrimonies left by parents. Prove it,
One thrives by cheating; shallow fools and unthrifts,
Are game knaves only sly at: then a fellow
Presumes on his hair, and that his back can toil
for fodder from the city, lies: another
Reputed valiant, lives by the sword, and takes up
Quarrels or braves them, as the novice likes,
To guild his reputation, most improbable.
A word of desperate undertakings, possibly,
Procures some hungry meals, some tavern surfeits,
Some frippery to hide nakedness: perhaps
The scambling half a ducat now and then
To roar and noise it with the tattling hostess,
For a week's lodging: these are pretty shifts,
Souls bankrupt of their royalty submit to.
Give me a man, whose practice and experience,
Conceives not barely the philosopher's stone,
But indeed has it, one whose wit's his Indies.
The poor is most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You're pleasant
In new discoveries of fortune; use them
With moderation, Livio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Such wild language
Was wont to be a stranger to your custom;
However , brother, you are pleased to vent it,
I hope for recreation.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Name and honour.
What are they? A mere sound without supportance,
A begging chastity, youth, beauty, handsomeness,
Discourse, behaviour which might charm attention,
And curse the gazer's eyes into amazement;
Are nature's common bounties. So are diamonds
Uncut, so flowers unworn, so silkworms webs
Unwrought, gold unrefined, than all those glories
Are of esteem, when used and set at price,
There's no dark sense in this.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I understand not
The drift on't, nor how meant, nor yet to whom.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pray brother be more plain.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: First Romanello,
this for your satisfaction: if you waste
More hours in courtship to this maid, my sister,
Weighing her competency with your own,
You go about to build without foundation;
So that care will prove void.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A sure acquittance,
If I must be discharged.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Next Castamela,
To thee (My own loved sister) let me say
I have not been so bountiful, in showing
To fame, the treasure, which this age hath opened,
As thy true value merits.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You are merry.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: My jealousy of thy fresh blooming years,
Prompted a fear of husbanding too charily
Thy growth to such perfection, as no flattery
Of are can perish now.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Here's talk in riddles.
Brother, th'exposition?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I'll no longer
Chamber thy freedom, we have been already
Thrifty enough in our low fortunes, henceforth
Command thy liberty, with that thy pleasures.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is't come to this?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You're wondrous full of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Ladies of birth an I quality are suitors
For being known t'ee, I have promised, sister,
They shall partake your company.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What lady es,
Where, when, how, who?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A day, a week, a month
Sported amongst such beauties, is a gain
On time, they're young, wife, noble, fair, and chaste.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Chaste?

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Castamela chaste, I would not hazard
My hopes, my joys of thee, on dangerous trial.
Yet if (As it may chance) a neat clothed merriment
Pass without blush in tattling to the words,
Fall not too broad, 'tis but a pastime smiled at
Amongst yourselves in counsel, but beware
Of being overheard.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: This is pretty.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I doubt I know not what yet must be silent.

div.stage: Enter Troylo, Floria, Clarella, Silvia and Nitido.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: They come as soon as spoke of — sweetest fair-ones
My sister cannot but conceive this honour
Particular in your respects: dear sir
You grace us in your favours.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Virtuous lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: We are your servants.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your sure friends.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Society,
May fix us in a league.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: All fitly welcome.
I find not reason (Gentle ladies) whereon
To cast this debt of mine, but my acknowledgement
Shall study to pay thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sweet beauty,
Your brother hath indeed been too much churl
In this concealment from us all, who love him,
Of such desired a presence.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Please to enrich us
With your wished amity.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Our coach attends;
We cannot be denied:

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Command it Nitido.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Ladies, I shall, now for a lusty harvest.
'Twill prove a cheap year, should these barns be filled once,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother one word in private.

sp.speaker: Livio.
sp.l: Phew — anon
I shall instruct at large. — we are prepared
And easily entreated; 'tis good manners
Not to be troublesome.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Thou art perfect Livio.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Whether — but — he's my brother.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fair, your arm.
I am your usher lady.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: As you please sir.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I wait you to your coach,
Some two hours hence.
I shall return again.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Troylo-savelli,
Next heir unto the marquess? and the page too?
The marquis'd own page, Livio transformed
Into a sudden bravery, and altered
In nature, or I dream? amongst the ladies,
I not remember I have seen one face.
There's cunning in these changes, I am resolute,
Or to pursue the trick on't, or lose labour.

div.head: Actus ii.
div.stage: Enter Flavio supported by Camillo, and Vespuci.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.l: Not yet returned.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The lord our husband,
We mean, unkind! four hours are almost past,
(But twelve short minutes wanting by the glass)
Since we broke company, was never (Gentlemen)
Poor Princess used so?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: With your gracious favour,
Peers great in rank and place, ought of necessity
To attend on state employments.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: For such duties,
are all their toil and labour, but their pleasures
Flow in the beauties they enjoy, which conquers
All sense of other travail.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Trimly spoken.
When we were common, mortal, and a subject,
As other creatures of heavens making are,
(The more the pity) bless us! how we waited
For the huge play day when the pageants fluttered
About the city, for we then were certain,
The madam courtiers, would vouchsafe to visit us,
And call us by our names, and eat our viands:
Nay give us leave to sit at the upper end
Of our own tables, telling us how welcome
They'd make us, when we came to court: full little
Dreamt I at that time of the wind that blew me
Up to the weathercock of th'honours, now
Are thrust upon me, but we bear the burden,
Were't twice as much as 'tis, the next great feast,
We'll grace the city wives (Poor souls) and see
How they'll behave themselves, before our presence.
You two shall wait on us.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: With best observance,
And glory in our service.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We are creatures
Made proud in your commands.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Believe't you are so
And you shall find us readier in your pleasures,
Than you in your obedience, fie methinks
I have an excellent humour to be pettish;
A little toysome, 'tis a pretty sign
Of breeding, is't not fit? I 〈◊〉 indeed 〈◊〉
Long for some strange good things now.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Such news, madam.
Would overjoy my lord your husband.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Cause
Bonfires and bell ringings

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I must be with child then,
An't be but for the public jollity,
Or lose my longings, which were mighty pity.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sweet fates forbid it.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Noblest lady —

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Rudeness
Keep off, or I shall — saucy groom, learn manners,
Go swab amongst your goblins.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Let him stay,
The fellow I have seen, and now remember
His name, Fabricio.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Your poor creature lady;
Out of your gentleness, please you to consider
The brief of this petition, which contains
All hope of my last fortunes.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Give it from him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Here madam — mark Vespucci, how the
Wittol stares on his sometime wife! sure he imagines
To be a cuckold, by consent, is purchase
Of appprobation in a state.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Good reason.
The gain reprieved him from bankerours statute,
And filed him in the charter of his freedom.
She had seen the fellow, didst observe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Most punctually.
Could call him by his name too, why 'tis possible,
She has not yet forgotten of was her husband.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: That were strange, o 'tis a precious trinket.
Was ever puppet so slipped up?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The tale
Of Venus' cat (Man) changed into a woman,
Was emblem but to this, she turns.

sp.speaker: Vef
sp.l: He stands just like action in the painted cloth

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Friend we have read, and weighed the sum
of what your scrivener, which in effect
Is meant your counsel learned, has drawn for ye:
'Tis a fair hand insooth, but the contents
Somewhat unseasonable, for let us tell ye,
You've been a spender, a vain spender, wasted
Your stock of credit, and of wares unthriftily.
You are a faulty man, and should we urge
Our lord as often for supplies, as shame,
Or wants drive you to ask, it might be construed
An impudence, which we defy, an impudence,
Base in base women, but in noble sinful.
Are ye not ashamed yet of yourself?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Great lady,
Of my misfortunes I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So, so,
This jeer twangs roundly, does it not Vespucci?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Why here's a lady worshipful.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen,
Retire awhile; this fellow shall resolve
Some doubts that stick about me.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: As you please.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: To thee Fabricio, o the change is cruel
Since I find some small leisure, I must justify,
Thou art unworthy of the name of man.
These holy vows, which we by bonds of faith,
Recorded in the register of truth,
Were kept by me unbroken, no assaults
Of jousts of courtship from the great and wanton,
No threats, nor sense of poverty (To which
Thy riots had betrayed me) could betray
My warrantable thoughts, to impure folly.
Why wouldst thou force me miserable?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: The scorn
Of rumor, is reward enough, to brand
My lewder actions, 'twas I thought impossible,
A beauty fresh as was your youth, could brook
the last of my decays,

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Did I complain?
My sleeps between thine arms, were even as sound,
My dreams as harmless, my contents as free,
As when the best of plenty crowned our bride bed.
Amongst some of a mean, but quiet fortune,
Distrust of what they call their own, or jealousy
Of those whom in their bosoms they possess
Without control, begets a self unworthiness;
For which fear, or what is worst desire,
Or paltry gain, they practise art, and labour to
Pander their own wives: those wives whose innocence
Stranger to language, spoke obedience only,
And such a wife was Flavia to Fabritio.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: My loss is irrecoverable.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Call not
Thy wickedness thy loss; without my knowledge
Thou sold'st me, and in open court protestdest
A precontract unto another, falsely
To justify a separation, wherein
Could I offend to be believed thy strumpet,
In best sense an adulteress? so conceived
In all opinions, that I am shaken off,
Even from mine own blood, which although I boast
Not noble, yet 'twas not mean, for Romanello
Mine only brother, shuns me, and abhors
To own me for his sister.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed,
I am the shame of mankind.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I live happy
In this great lords love, now, but could his cunning
Have trained me to dishonour, we had never
Been sundered by'th temptation of his purchase.
Introth Fabritio, I am little proud of
My unsought honours, and so far from triumph,
That I am not more fool, to such as honour me,
then to myself, who hate this antique carriage!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: You are an angel rather to be worshipped,
Then grossly to be talked with.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Keep those ducats;
I shall provide you better: 'twere a bravery,
Could you forget the place wherein you've rendered
Your name for ever hateful.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: I will do't,
Do't excellentest goodness, and conclude
My days in silent goodness.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You may prosper
In Spain, in France, or elsewhere, as in Italy.
Besides, you are a scholar bred, however
You interrupted study with commerce,
I'll think of your supplies, mean time, pray, storm not
At my behaviour t'ee, I have forgotten acquaintance
With mine own — keep your first distance —

div.stage: Enter Julio, Camillo, Vespuci Camillo, who is near, Vespuci.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What, our lady's cast familiar.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O my stomach
Wambles at fight of — sick, sick, I am sick —
I saint at heart — kiss me, nay prithee quickly,
Or I shall swoon — you've stayed a sweet while from me.
And this companion to — beshrew him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Dearest,
Thou art my health, my blessing — turn the bankrupt
Out of my doors — sirrah, I'll have thee whipped.
If thou com'st here again.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hence, hence you vermin.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How is't my best of joys?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Prettily mended.
Now we have our own lord here: I shall never
Endure to spare you long out of my sight.
See what the thing presented.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A petition,
belike for some new charity.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We must not
Be troubled with his needs, a wanting creature
Is monstruous, is as ominous — fie, upon't.
Dispatch the silly mushroom once for all,
And send him with some pittance out o'th country,
Where we may hear no more of him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thy will shall stand a law, my Flavia,

sp.speaker: Flau.
sp.l: You have been
In private with our fellow peers now: sha'not we
Know how the business stands, sure in some country,
Ladies are privy counsellors, I warrant ye:
Are they not think ye? there the land is (Doubtless)
Most politicly governed; all the women
We are swords and breeches, I have heard most certainly,
Such sights were excellent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thou'rt a matchless pleasure:
No life is sweet without thee, in my heart
Reign empress, and be styled thy Julio's sovereign.
My only, precious dear:

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: We'll prove no less t'ee.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sea sick ashore still? thou couldst rarely scape
A calenture in a long voyage, Livio,
Who in a short one, and at home art subject
To such faint stomach qualms, no cordials comfort
The business of thy thoughts, for ought I see:
What ails thee (Man) be merry, hang up jealousies.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Who, ay, I jealous? no, no, here's no cause
In this place 'tis a nunnery, a retirement
For meditation, all the difference extant
But puzzles, only bar belief, not grounds it,
Rich services in place! soft and fair lodgings,
Varieties of recreations, exercise
Of music in all changes? neat attendance?
Princely, nay royal furniture of garments?
Satiety of gardens, orchards, water works,
Pictures so ravishing, that ranging eyes,
Might dwell upon a dotage of conceit,
Without a single wish for livelier substance?
The great world in a little world of fancy,
Is here abstracted: no temptation proffered
But such as fools and mad folks can invite to?
And yet —

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And yet your reason cannot answer
Th' objections of your fears, which argue danger.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.l: Danger? dishonour, Troylo: were my sister
In safety from those charms, I must confess
I could live here for ever.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: But you could not.
I can assure ye, for't were then scarce possible,
A door might opent'ee, hardly a loophole,

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: My presence then is usher to her ruin,
And loss of her, the fruit of my preferment.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Briefly partake a secret, but be sure
To lodge it in the inmost of thy bosom,
Where memory may not find it for discovery;
By our firm truth of friendship, I require thee.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: By our firm truth of friendship, I subscribe
To just conditions.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Our great uncle marquess,
Disabled from his cradle, by an impotence
In nature first, that impotence, since seconded
And rendered more infirm, by a fatal breach
Received in fight against the Turkish galleys
Is made uncapable of any faculty,
Of active manhood, more than what affections
Proper unto his sex, must else distinguish:
So that no helps of art can warrant life,
Should he transcend the bounds his weakness limits.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: On, I attend with eagerness.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: 'Tis strange,
Such natural defects at no time cheques
A full and free sufficiency of spirit;
Which flows, both in so clear and fixed a strength,
That to confirm belief (It seems) where nature
Is in the body lame, she is supplied
In fine proportion of the mind, a word
Concludes all; to a man his enemy,
He is a dangerous threatening: but to women,
However pleasurable, no way cunning
To show abilities of friendship, other
Than what his outward senses can delight in,
Or charge and bounty court with.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good, good — Troylo,
O that I had a lusty faith to credit it,
Though none of all this wonder should be possible.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: As I love honour, and an honest name,
I falter not (My Livio) in one syllable,

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: News admirable, 'tis, 'tis so — pish I know it,
Yet 'a has a kind heart of his own to girls,
Young, handsome girls; yes, yes, so a' may,
'Tis granted — 'a would now and then be piddling,
And play the wanton, like a fly that dallies
About a candle's flame: then scorch his wings,
Drop down, and creep away, ha?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hardly that too;
To look upon fresh beauties, to discourse
In an unblushing merriment of words,
To hear them play or sing, and see them dance,
To pass the time in pretty amorous questions,
Read a chaste verse, of love, or prattle riddles,
Is th' height of his temptations.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Send him joy on't.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: His choices are not of the courtly train;
Nor city's practice; but the country's innocence,
Such as are gentle-born, not meanly; such,
to whom both gaudiness and apelike fashions
Are monstrous; such as cleanliness and decency,
Prompt to a virtuous envy, such as study
A knowledge of no danger, but themselves.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Well, I have lived in ignorance: the ancients,
Who chatted of the golden age, feigned trifles.
Had they dreamt this, they would have truthed it heaven.
I mean an earthly heaven, less it is not.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Yet is this bachelor miracle not free
From the epidemical headache.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: The yellows.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Huge jealous fits, admitting none to enter
But me, his page, and barber, with an eunuch,
And an old guardianess, it is a favour
Not common, that the licence of your visits,
To your own sister, now and then is wink't at.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: But why are you his instrument, his nephew?
'Tis ominous in nature.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Not in policy.
Being his heir, I may take truce a little,
With mine own fortunes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Knowing how things stand too.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: At certain seasons, as the humour takes him,
A set of music are permitted peaceably,
To cheer their solitariness, provided
They're strangers, not acquainted near the city,
But never the same twice, pardon him that;
Nor must their stay exceed an hour, or two
At farthest; as at this wise wedding, wherefore
His barber is the master to instruct
The lasses both in song and dance, by him
Trained up in either quality.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A caution happily studied.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Farther to prevent
Suspicion, a' has married his young barber
To the old matron, and withal is pleased,
report should mutter him a mighty man
For th'game, to take off all suspicion
Of insufficiency, and this strict company
A' calls his bower of fancies.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes and properly,
Since all his recreations are in fancy.
I'm infinitely taken — sister? marry
Would I had sisters in a plenty, Troylo,
So to bestow them all, and turn them fancies.
Fancies? Why 'tis a pretty name methinks.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Something remains, which in conclusion shortly.
Shall take thee fuller — hark, the wedding jollity!
With a bridecake on my life, to grace the nuptials!
Perhaps the ladies will turn songsters.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Silence.

div.stage: Enter Secco, Castamela, Floria, Clarella, Silvia, Morosa, and Spadone.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Passing neat and exquisite, I protest fair creatures; these honours to our solemnity, are liberal and uncommon; my spouse and myself with our posterity, shall prostitute our services, to your bounties, shall's not duckling?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes honey suckle, and do as much for them one day, if things stand right as they should stand, bill, pigeon do; thou'st be my catamountain, and I thy sweet briar, honey, we'll lead you to kind examples (Pretty ones) believe it, and you shall find us, one in one, whiles hearts do last.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Ever mine own, and ever.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Well said old touch hole.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: All happiness, all joy.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: A plenteous issue,
A fruitful womb — thou hast a blessing Secco.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Indeed a' has sir, if ye know all, as I conceive you know enough, if not the whole: for you have (I may
say) tried me to the quick, through and through, and most of my carriage, from time to time.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: 'Twould wind-break a moil, or a ringed mare, to vie burdens with her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's that you mumble, gelding, shey.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Nothing forsooth, but that you're bouncing couple well met, and 'twere pity to part ye, though you hung together in a smoky chimney.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Twere e'en pity indeed, Spadone, nay thou'st a foolish loving nature of thine own, and withheld well to plain dealings of my conscience.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Thank your brideship — your bawdship.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Our sister is not merry.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sadness cannot
Become a bridal harmony.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: At a wedding, free spirits are required.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You should dispense
With serious thoughts, now lady.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Well said gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Fie Castamela fie,

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: A dance, a dance.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By any means, the day is not complete else.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed he be excused,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By no means, lady.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: We are all suitors.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: With your pardons, spare me
For this time, grant me licence to look on.
Command your pleasures, lady, — every one hand
Your partner — nay, Spadone, must make one.
These merriments are free.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: With all my heart, I'm sure I am not the heaviest
In the company.
Strike up for the honour of the bride and bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: So, so, here's art in motion: on all parts,
Ye have bestirred ye nimbly,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I could dance now,
E'en till I dropped again; but want of practice
Denies the scope of breath or so, yet sirrah,
My catamountain, do not I trip quickly,
And with a grace too, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Light as a feather.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Sure you are not without a stick of licorice in your pocket forsooth; you have I believe stout lungs of your own, you swim about so roundly without rubs; 'tis a tickling sight to be young still.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Madam Morosa?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Child.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: To you in secret.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: That earwig scatters the troop now, I'll go near to fit 'em.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: My lord upon my life.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Then we must sever.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen, your ears.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: O 'twas ever a wanton monkey — a' will wriggle into a starting hole so cleanly — and it had been on my wedding day, — I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Sayest so Spadone?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, I prate sometimes beside the purpose, whoreson lecherous weasel?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Look, look, look how officious the little knave is — but —

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Why? there's the business, butts on ones forehead, are but scurvy butts.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Spadone, discharge the fiddlers instantly.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Yes, I know my postures-oh monstruous butts.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Attend within, sweeting, — your pardons
Gentlemen; to your recreations dear virgins:
Page have a care,

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: My duty reverend madam.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Livio away — sweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Suddenly I shall return, enough for a round temptation.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: One gentle word in private with your ladyship. I shall
Not hold you long.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What means this huddle
Of flying several ways thus? who has frighted 'em?
They live not at devotion here, or pension!
Pray quit me of distrust.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: May it please your goodness,
You'll find him even in every point as honourable,
As flesh and blood can vouch him:

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ha, him? whom?
What him?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: He will not press beyond his bounds.
He will but chat and toy, and feel your —

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Guard me,
A powerful genius! feel —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Your hands to kiss them.
Your fair, pure, white hands, what strange business is it?
These melting twins of ivory, but softer
Than down of turtles, shall but feed the appetite —

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A rape upon my ears.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The appetite
Of his poor ravished eye; should he swell higher
In his desires, and soar upon ambition
Of rising in humility, by degrees;
Perhaps a' might crave leave to clap —

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fond woman,
In thy grave sinful,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Clap or pat the dimples,
Where loves tomb stands erected on your cheeks.
Else pardon those slight exercises, pretty one,
His lordship is as harmless a weak implement,
As ere young lady trembled under.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Lordship!
(Stead me my modest anger) 'tis belike then
religious matron) some great man's prison,
Where virgins honours suffer martyrdom.
And you are their tormentor; let's lay down
Our ruined names to the insulter's mercy!
Let's sport and smile on scandal (Rare calamity,
What hast thou toiled me in?) you named his lordship,
Some gallant youth and fiery?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No, no deed la.
A very grave stale bachelor (My dainty one)
There's the conceit: he's none of your hot rovers,
Who ruffle at first dash, and so disfigure
Your dresses, and your sets of blush at once.
He's wise in years, and of a temperate warmth;
Mighty in means and power: and withal liberal.
A wanton in his wishes, but else, farther,
A' cannot — cause — a' cannot.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Cannot, prithee,
Be plainer: I begin to like thee strangely.
What cannot?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You urge timely, and to purpose,
A' cannot do — the truth is truth — do, any thing,
(As one should say) that's any thing, put case
(I do but put the case forsooth) a' find ye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My stars I thank ye, for being ignorant,
Of what this old in mischief can intend.
And so we might be merry, bravely merry.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You hit it — what else — she is cunning — look ye,
Pray lend your hand forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why prithee take it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You have a delicate moist palm — umh — can ye relish that tickle? there.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And laugh if need were.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And laugh, why now you have it, what hurt pray
Perceive ye? there's all, all, go to, you want tutoring,
Are an apt scholar, I'll neglect no pains
For your instruction.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do not, but his lordship,
What may his lordship be?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No worse man
Than marquess of Sienna, the great master
Of this small family, your master found him,
A bounteous benefactor, has advanced him,
The gentleman o'th horse, in a shot time
He means to visit you himself in person,
As kind, as loving, an old man.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: We'll meet him
With a full flame of welcome, is't the marquess?
No worse?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No worse I can assure your ladyship,
The only free maintainer of the fancies.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fancies? How mean ye that.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The pretty souls
Who are companions in the house, all daughters
To honest virtuous parents, and right worshipful.
A kind of chaste collapsed ladies.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Chaste too, and yet collapsed?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Only in their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Sure I must be a fancy in the number.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: A fancy principal, I hope you'll fashion
Your entertainment, when the marquess courts you,
As that I may stand blameless.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Free suspicion. My brother's raiser?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Merely.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My supporter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: An old man and a lover?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: True, there's the music, the content, the harmony.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And I myself a fancy?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You are pregnant.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The chance is thrown, I now am fortune's minion,
I will be bold and resolute.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Blessing on thee.

div.head: Actus iii.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Prosper me now my fate; some better genius
Than such a one, as waits on troubled passions,
Direct my courses to a noble issue.
My thoughts have wandered in a labyrinth,
But if the clew I have laid hold on, fail not,
I shall tread out the toil of these dark paths
In spite of politic reaches — I am punished
In mine own hopes, by her unlucky fortunes,
Whose fame is ruined; Flavia, my lost sister!
Lost to report, by her unworthy husband,
Though heightened by a greatness, in whose mixtures,
I hate to claim a part — o welcome, welcome,
Dear boy! thou keepest time with my expectations
As justly, as the promise of my bounties
Shall reckon with thy service.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: I have fashioned the means of your admittance.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Precious Nitido.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: More, have bethought me of a shape, a quaint one,
You may appear in, safe and unsuspected.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou'rt an ingenious boy.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Beyond all this;
Have so contrived the feat, that at first sight,
Troylo himself shall court your entertainment:
Nay, force you to vouchsafe it.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou'st out done all counsel, and all cunning.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: True, I have sir
Fadged nimbly in my practises: but surely,
There are some certain clogs, some roguish staggers,
Somewhat shall I call 'em in the business?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Nitido,
what faint now? dear heart bear up, what staggers,
What clogs? let me remove 'em.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Am I honest
In this discovery?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Honest, pish is that all?
By this rich purse, and by the twenty ducats
Which line it, I will answer for thy honesty,
Against all Italy, and prove it perfect,
Besides, remember, I am bound to secrecy.
Thou'lt not betray thyself.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: All fears are cleared then.
But if —

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If what? out with't.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: If we're discovered,
You'll answer I am honest still?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Dost doubt it?

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Not much; I have your purse in pawn fort.
Now to the shape, and know the wits in Florence,
Who in the great Duke's court, buffoons his compliment,
According to the change of meats in season,
At every free lords table,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Or free meetings
In taverns, there a' sits at the upper end,
And eats, and prates, a' cares not how nor what.
The very quaik of fashions, the very he that
Wears a steletto on his chin.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: You have him.
Like such a thing must you appear, and study
Amongst the ladies in a formal foppery,
To vent some curiosity of language,
Above their appehensions, or your own,
Indeed beyond sense, you are the more the person.
Now amorous, then scurvy, sometimes bawdy,
The same man still, but evermore fantastical,
As being the suppositor to laughter:
It hath saved charge in physic.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: When occasion
Offers itself (For where it does or not,
I will be bold to take it) I may turn
To some one in the company; and changing
My method talk of state, and rail against
Th'imployment of the time, mislike the carriage
Of places, and mislike that men of parts,
Of merit, such as myself am, are not
Thrust into public action: 'twill set off
A privilege I challenge from opinion,
With a more lively current.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: On my modesty,
You are some kin to him — signior Prugnioli!
Signior Mushrumpo!
Leap but into his antic garb, and trust me
You'll fit it to a thought.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The time?

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: As suddenly
As you can be transformed, — for the event,
'Tis pregnant.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yet my pretty knave, thou hast not
Discovered where fair Castamela lives;
Nor how, nor amongst whom.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Pish, it more queres,?
Till your own eyes inform, be silent, else
Take back your earnest, what, turn woman? fie;
Be idle and inquisitive?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No more.
I shall be speedily provided, ask for
A note at mine own lodging.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: I'll not fail ye,
Assuredly, I will not fail you signior;
My fine in amorato — twenty ducats?
They're half his quarter's income — love, o love,
What a pure madness art thou? I shall fit him,
Fit, quit and split him too — most bounteous sir.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Boy, thou art quick and trusty,
Be withal close and silent, and thy pains
Shall meet a liberal addition.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Though sir,
I'm but a child, yet you shall find me —

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Man
In the contrivements; I will speak for thee.
Well 'adoes relish the disguise!

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Most greedily
Swallows it with a liquorish delight:
Will instantly be shaped in't instantly,
And on my conscience, sir, the supposition
Strengthened by supposition, will transform him
Into the beast itself 'a does resemble.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Spend that, and look for more boy.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Sir, it needs not:
I have already twenty ducats pursed
In a gay case, alas sir, to you, my service
Is but my duty.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Modesty in pages
Shows not a virtue, boy, when it exceeds
Good manners. Where must we meet?

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: Sir at's lodging,
Or near about: he will make haste believe it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Wait th'opportunity, and give me notice.
I shall attend.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: If I miss my part, hang me.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Come thou'rt caught Camillo.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Away, away,
That were a jest indeed; I caught?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: The lady
Does scatter glances, wheels her round, and smiles;
Steals an occasion to ask how the minutes
each hour have run in progress; then, thou kissest
All thy four fingers, crouchest and sighest faintly:
Dear beauty, if my watch keep fair decorum,
Three quarters have near passed the figure x.
Or as the time of day goes —

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So Vespucci,
This will not do, I read it on thy forehead,
The grain of thy complexion is quite altered.
Once 'twas a comely brown, 'tis now of late
A perfect green and yellow; sure prognosticates
Of th'over flux o'th gall, and melancholy,
Symptoms of love and jealousy, poor soul.
Quoth she, the she, why hang thy looks like bell-ropes
Out of the wheels? thou flinging down thy eyes
Low at her feet, replied'st, because, o sovereign
The great bell of my heart is cracked, and never
Can ring in tune again, till't be new cast
By one only skilful foundress. — hereat
She turned aside, winked, thou stoodst still and stared'st
I did observ't, be plain, what hope?

sp.speaker: Vesp.
sp.l: She loves thee;
Dotes on thee: in my hearing told her lord
Camillo was the Pyramus and Thisbe
Of courtship, and of compliment: ah ha!
She nicked it there. I envy not thy fortunes;
For to say truth, thou'rt handsome, and deservest her,
Were she as great again as she is.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I handsome?
Alas, alas, a creature of heavens making,
There's all! but sirrah, prithee let's be sociable;
I do confess, I think the goody-madam
May possibly be compassed; I resolve too,
To put in for a share; come what can come on't.

sp.speaker: Vesp.
sp.l: A pretty toy 'tis, since thou'rt open breasted,
Camillo I presume she is wanton,
And therefore mean to give the souse, whenever
I find the game on wing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Let us consider,
She's but a merchant's leavings.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Hatched i'th country,
And fledged i'th city.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis a common custom
Amongst friends (They are not friends else) chiefly gallants,
To trade by turns in such like frail commodities.
The one is but reversioner to tother.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Why 'tis the fashion man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Most free and proper,
One surgeon, one apothecary.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Thus then;
When I am absent, use the gentlest memory
Of my endowments, my unblemished services
To ladies' favours: with what faith and secrecy.
I live in her commands, whose special courtesies,
Oblige me to particular engagements.
I'll do as much for thee.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: With this addition
Camillo (Best of fairs) a man so bashful,
So simply harmless, and withal so constant,
Yet resolute in all! true rights of honour;
That to deliver him in perfect character,
Were to detract from such a solid virtue
As reigns not in another soul — he is

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: The thing a mistress ought to wish her servant;
Are we agreed?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Most readily on tother side,
Unto the lord her husband, talk as coursely
Of one another as we can.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: I like it, so shall we sift her love, and his opinion.

sp.speaker: Julio
sp.l: Be thankful (Fellow) to a noble mistress;
Two hundred ducats are no trifling sum,
nor common alms.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: You must not loiter lazily,
And speak about the town my friend in taverns,
In gaming houses, nor sneak after dinner
To public shows, to interludes, in riot,
To some lewd painted baggage, tricked up gaudily,
Like one of us; o fie upon 'em giblets!
I have been told they ride in coaches, flaunt it
In brave ries, so rich, that it is scarce possible
How to distinguish one of these vile naughty packs,
From true and arrant ladies — they'll inveigle
Your substance and your body, think on that,
I say your body, look to't,
Is't not sound counsel?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: 'Tis more, 'tis heavenly.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: What hope Camillo now if this tune hold?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hope fair enough, Vespucci, now as ever:
Why any woman in her husband's presence
Can say no less.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and she hath leave here.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Madam, your care and charity at once,
Have so new moulded my resolves,
That henceforth whene'er my mention
Falls into report,
It shall requite this bounty, I am travelling
To a new world.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I like your undertakings.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: New world, where's that I pray? good, if you light on
A parrot or a monkey that has qualities
Of a new fashion, think on me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Yes, lady
I, I shall think on you; and my devotions
Tendered where they are due in single meekness,
With purer flames will mount with free increase
Of plenty, honours, full contents, full blessings,
Truth and affection twixt your lord and you.
So with my humblest best leave, I turn from you,
Never as now I am to appear before ye.
All joys dwell here and lasting.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Prithee sweetest
Hark in your ear — beshrew't, the brim of your hat
Struck in mine eye — dissemble honest tears
The griefs my heart does labour in — smarts
Unmeasurably.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A chance, a chance, 'twill off;
Suddenly off, forbear, this handkercher
But makes it worse.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Wink madam with that eye.
The pain will quickly pass.

sp.speaker: Vesp.
sp.l: Immediately,
I know it by experience.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yes, I find it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Spare us a little gentlemen: speak freely.
What were't thou saying dearest?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Do you love me?
Answer in sober sadness, I'm your wife now;
I know my place and power.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What's this riddle?
Thou hast thyself replied to thine own question,
In being married to me, a sure argument
Of more than protestation.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Such it should be
Were you as other husbands: 'tis granted,
A woman of my state may like good clothes,
Choice diet, many servants, change of merriments,
All these I do enjoy; and wherefore not?
Great ladies should command their own delights,
And yet for all this, I am used but homely,
But I am served even well enough.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Flavia
I understand not what thou wouldst

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pray pardon me;
I do confess I'm foolish, very foolish;
Trust me indeed I am, for I could cry
Mine eyes out, being in the weeping humour:
You know I have a brother.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Romanello,
An unkind brother.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Right, right, since you bosomed
My latter youth, he never would vouchsafe
As much as to come near me. O, it mads me,
Being but two, that we should live at distance;
As if I were a castaway, and you
For your part take no care on't nor attempted
To draw him hither.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Say the man be peevish,
Must I petition him?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Yea marry must ye,
Or else you love not me; not see my brother?
Yes I will see him, so I will, will see him.
You hear't, — o my good lord, dear gentle, prithee,
You shan't be angry; alas I know poor gentleman,
'A bears a troubled mind: but let us meet
And talk a little, we perhaps may chide
At first, shed some few tears, and then be quiet;
There's all.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Write to him, and invite him hither,
Or go to him thyself. Come, no more sadness,
I'll do what thou canst wish.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: And in requital,
Believe I shall say something that may settle
A constancy of peace, for which thoul't thank me.

sp.speaker: Secco.
sp.p: The rarest fellow, Spadone, so full of gambols, 'a talks so humorously, does a not, so carelessly? O rich! O, my hope of posterity! I could be in love with him.

sp.speaker: Spadone.
sp.p:
His tongue trolls like a mill-clack: 'a touses the lady sisters, as a tumbling dog does young rabbits;
heigh here, dab there, your madonna; 'a has a catch at her too: there's a trick in the business; I am a dunce, else I say a shrewd one.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Jump with me, I smell a trick too, if I could tell what.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Who brought him in? that would be known?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: That did signior Troylo; I saw the page part at the door; some trick still, go to wife, I must and I will have an eye to this gear.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: A plain case, roguery, brokage and roguery, or call me bulchin. Fancies, quoth 'a? rather frenzies. We shall all roar shortly: turn madcaps, lie open to what comes first I may stand to't. That boy page, is a naughty boy page; let me feel your forehead, ha, o, hum, — yes — there, — there again; I'm sorry for ye, a handsaw cannot cure ye, monstrous and apparent.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: What, what, what, what, what Spadone?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: What what what what, nothing but velvet tips you are of the first head yet: have a good heart man, a cuckold though 'a be a beast, wears invisible horns; else we might know a city bull from a country calf, — villainous boy still.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: My razor shall be my weapon, my razor.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Why? he's not come to the honour of a beard yet, he needs no shaving.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: I will trim him and tram him.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Nay she may do well enough for one.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: One, ten, a hundred, a thousand; ten thousand: do beyond arithmetic Spadone, I speak it with some passion, I am a notorious cuckold.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Gross and ridiculous, — look ye, point blank I dare not swear that this same mountbancking new-come foist, is at least a procurer in the business; if not a pretender himself: but I think what I think.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p:
He, Troylo, Livio, the page, that hole-creeping page; all horn me sirrah; I'll forgive thee from my heart:
dost not thou drive a trade too in my bottom.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: A likely matter, alas I'm metamorphosed I, be patient you'll mar all else.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Now, now, now, now, the games rampant, rampant.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Leave your wild fegaries, and learn to be a tame antic, or I'll observe no longer.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha.

div.stage: Enter Troylo, Castamela, Floria, Clarella Silvia, Morosa, and Romanello, like a courtly mountebank.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You are extremely busy signior.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Courtly,
Without a fellow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have a stabbing wit.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But are you always, when you press on ladies
Of mild and easy nature, so much satire;
So tart and keen as we do taste ye now?
It argues a lean brain.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Gip to your beauties,
You would be fair forsooth, you would be monsters;
Fair women are such, monsters to be seen
Are rare, and so are they.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Bear with him ladies.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: He is a foul-mouthed man.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Whore, bitch — fox, treedle — fa la la la —

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How's that my cat a mountain?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Hold her there boy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Were you ere in love fine signior?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yes for sport's sake;
But soon forgotten it. He that rides a gallop
Is quickly weary. I esteem of love
As of a man in some huge place; it puzzles
Reason, distracts the freedom of the soul;
Renders a wise man fool, and a fool wise
In's own conceit, not else it yields effects
of pleasure travail, bitter, sweet; war, peace;
Thorns, roses; prayers, curses; longings, surfeits;
Despair, and then a rope: o my trim lover,
Yes, I have loved a score at once.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Out stallion, as I am a man and no man, the baboon lies I dare swear abominably.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Inhumanly, — keep your bow close, vixen.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Beshrew your fingers if you be in earnest:
You pinch too hard, go to, I'll pare your nails for't.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: She means your horns, there's a bob for you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Spruce signior, if a man may love so many,
Why may not a fair lady have like privilege
Of several servants?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Answer that, the reason
Holds the same weight.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Marry and so it does,
Though he would spit his gall out.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Mark that secco.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: D'ye pump for a reply?

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: The learned differ
In that point; grand and famous scholars often
Have argued pro and con, and left it doubtful;
Volumes have been writ on't. If then great clerks
Suspend their resolutions, 'tis a modesty
For me to silence mine.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Dull and phlegmatic.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yet women sure in such a case are ever
More secret than men are.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yea and talk less.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That is a truth much fabled, never found
You secret? when your dresses blab your vanities;
Carnation for your points? there's a gross babbler:
Tawny, heigh ho, the pretty heart is wounded.
A knot of willow ribbons she's forsaken?
Another rides the cockhorse, green and azure,
Wince and cry we he like a colt unbroken:
but desperate black puts 'em in mind of fish days;
When lent spurs on devotion, there's a famine:
Yet love and judgement may help all this pother.
Where are they? not in females?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: In all sorts of men no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Else they were sots to choose.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To swear and flatter, sometimes lie for profit.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Not so forsooth, should love and judgement meet,
The old, the fool; the ugly and deformed
Could never be beloved; for example,
Behold these two; this madam and this shaver.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I do defy thee; am I old or ugly?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Tricks, knacks, devices, now it trolls about.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Troll let it stripling, thou hast yet firm footing
And needst not fear the cuckold's livery.
There's good philosophy fort, take this for comfort,
No horned beasts have teeth in either gums:
But thou art toothed on both sides, though she fail in't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: He's not jealous sirrah.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That's his fortune,
Women indeed more jealous are then men;
But men have more cause.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: There a rubbed your forehead, 'twas a tough blow.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: It smarts.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Pox on him, let him
Put's finger into any gums of mine,
He shall find I have teeth about me, sound ones.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You are a scurvy fellow, and I am made a coke's, an ass; and this same filthy crone's a flirt. Whope do me no harm good woman.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Now now he's in, I must not leave him so.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Morosa, what means this?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I know not I,
He pinched me, called me names, most filthy names.
Will ye part hence sir, I will set ye packing.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You were indeed too broad, too violent.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Here's nothing meant but mirth.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The gentleman
Hath been a little pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Somewhat bitter
Against our sex.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: For which I promise him
A ne'er proves choice of mine.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not I your choice.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: So she protested signior.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why you are moved sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hence, there enters
A civiller companion for fair ladies
Then such a sloven.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Beauties.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Time prevents us,
Love and sweet thoughts accompany this presence.

div.stage: Enter Octavio, Secco whispering him, Livio and Nitido.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Enough, slip off, and on your life be secret.
A lovely day, young creatures. To you Floria;
To you Clarella, Silvia, to all service:
But who is this fair stranger?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Castamela,
My sister, noble lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Let ignorance
Of what you were, plead my neglect of manners,
And this soft touch excuse it, you've enriched
This little family (Most excellent virgin)
With th'honour of your company.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I find them
Worthily graceful sir.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Are ye so taken?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here are no public sights nor courtly visitants,
Which youth and active blood might stray in thought for:
the companies are few, the pleasures single,
And rarely to be brooked, perhaps by any;
Not perfectly acquainted with this custom,
Are they not lovely one?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Sir, I dare answer
My sister's resolution. Free converse
Amongst so many of her sex, so virtuous,
She ever hath preferred before the surquedry
Of protestation, or the vainer giddiness
Of popular attendants.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Well played brother.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The meaning of this music.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Please your lordship,
It is the lady's hour for exercise
In song and dance.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I dare not be the author
Of truanting the time then, neither will I.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Walk on dear ladies.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: 'Tis a task of pleasure.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Be now my sister, stand a trial bravely:

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Remember my instructions, or —

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: With pardon.
You are not of the number I presume yet,
To be enjoined to hours. If you please,
We for a little while may sit as judges
Of their proficience, pray vouchsafe the favour.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I am sir in a place to be commanded,
As now the present urgeth.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No compulsion,
That were too hard a word; where you are sovereign
Your yea and nay is law: I have a suit tee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: For what sir?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: For your love.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: To whom? I am not
So weary of th'authority I hold
over mine own contents in sleeps and wakings;
That I'd resign my liberty to any
Who should control it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Neither I intend so,
Grant me an entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Of what nature?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To acknowledge me your creature.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O my lord.
You are too wise in years, too full of counsel
For my green inexperience.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Love dear maid,
Is but desire of beauty, and 'tis proper
For beauty to desire to be beloved.
I am not free from passion, though the current
Of a more lively heat runs slowly through me,
My heart is gentle, and believe fresh girl:
Thou shalt not wish for any full addition,
Which may adorn thy rarities to boast 'em;
That bounty can, withhold this academy.
Of silent pleasures is maintained, but only
To such a constant use.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You have belike then
A patent for concealing virgins, otherwise
Make plainer your intentions.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To be pleasant
In practice of some outward senses only
No more.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No, worse you dare not to imagine;
Where such an awful innocence, as mine is,
Outfaces every wickedness, your dotage
Has lullled you in. I scent your cruel mercies,
Your factress hath been tampering for my misery;
Your old temptation; your she-devil — bear with
A language which this place, and none but this, hath
Infected my tongue with. The time will come too,
When he (Unhappy man) whom your advancement
hath ruined by being spaniel to your fortunes,
Will curse a trained me hither — Livio,
I must not call him brother; this one act
Hath rent him off the ancestry he sprung from.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The proffer of a noble courtesy
Is checked it seems.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A courtesy? A bondage;
You are a great man vicious, much more vicious,
Because you hold a seeming league with charity
Of pestilent nature, keeping hospitality
For sensualists in your own sepulchre,
Even by your life time: yet are dead already.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How's this, come be more mild.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You chide me soberly,
Than sir I tune my voice to other music;
You are an eminent statist, be a father
To such unfriended virgins, as your bounty
Hath drawn into a scandal, you are powerful
In means. A bachelor, freed from the jealousies
Of wants, convert this privacy of maintenance
Into your own court: let this (As you call it)
Your academy have a residence there;
And there survey your charity yourself:
That when you shall bestow on worthy husbands
With fitting portions, such as you know worthy;
You may yield to the present age example,
And to posterity a glorious chronicle:
There were a work of piety: the other is
A scorn upon your tombstone; where the reader
Will but expound, that when you lived you pandered
Your own purse and your same. I am too bold sir,
Some anger and some pity hath directed
A wand'ring trouble.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Be not known what passages
The time hath lent, for once I can bear with ye.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I'll countenance the hazard of suspicion.
And be your guest a while.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Be — but hereafter —
I know not what — Livio.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed sir
I cannot part w'ye yet.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well then thou shalt not,
My precious Castamela — thou hast a sister,
A perfect sister Livio.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: All is inked here
Good soul indeed.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: I'd speak with you anon.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Come fair one.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: O I am cheated.

div.head: Act. iiii.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Prithee be serious.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Prithee interupt not
The paradise of my becharming thoughts,
Which mount my knowledge to the sphere I move in,
Above this useless tattle.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Tattle? Sister,
D'ye know to whom you talk this?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: To the gentleman
Of my lords horse, new stepped into the office:
'Tis a good place sir, if you can be thankful.
Demean your carriage in it, so that negligence
Or pride of your preferment oversway not
The grace you hold in his esteem. Such fortunes
Drop not down every day; observe the favour
that raised you to this fortune.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Thou mistakest sure
What person thou holdest speech with.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Strange and idle.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Is't possible? why? you are turned a mistress,
A mistress of the trim; beshrew me lady
You keep a stately port, but it becomes you not:
Our father's daughter, if I err not rarely,
Delighted in a softer humbler sweetness:
Not in a hey-de-gay of scurvy gallantry.
You do not brave it like a thing oth' fashion;
You ape the humour faintly.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Love dear maid
Is but desire of beauty, and 'tis proper
For beauty to desire to be beloved.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Fine sport, you mind not me; will you yet hear me madam?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Thou shalt not wish for any full addition,
Which may adorn thy rarities to boast 'em:
That bounty can withhold — I know I shall not.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: And so you clapped the bargain, the conceit on't
Tickles your contemplation. 'tis come out now,
A woman's tongue I see, some time or other
Will prove her traitor: this was all I sifted,
And here have found thee wretched.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: We shall flourish.
Feed high henceforth, man, and no more be straightened
Within the limits of an empty patience:
Nor tire our feeble eyes with gazing only
On greatness, which enjoys the swinge of pleasures.
But be ourselves the object of their envy,
To whom a service would have seemed ambition.
It was thy cunning Livio, I applaud it,
Fear nothing; I'll be thrifty in thy projects:
Want misery? may all such want as think on't;
Our footing shall stand firm.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: You are much witty.
Why caestamcla, this to me? you counterfeit
Most palpably. I am too well acquainted
With thy condition sister; if the marquess
Hath uttered one unchaste, one wanton syllable,
Provoking thy contempt: not all the flatteries
Of his assurance to our hopes of rising,
Can or shall slave our souls.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Indeed not so sir,
You are beside the point, most gentle signior,
I'll be no more your ward, no longer chambered,
Nor mewed up to the lure of your devotion:
Trust me, I must not, will not, dare not; surely
I cannot for my promise past; and sufferance
Of former trials hath too strongly armed me:
You may take this for answer.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: In such earnest?
Hath goodness left thee quite? fool thou art wand'ring
In dangerous fogs, which will corrupt the purity
Of every noble virtue dwelled within thee.
Come home again, home Castamela sister;
Home to thine own simplicity, and rather
Than yield thy memory up to the witchcraft
Of an abused confidence; be courted
For Romanello.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Romanello.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Scornest thou
The name? thy thoughts I find then are changed rebels
To all that's honest, that's to truth and honour.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: So sir, and in good time.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Thou art fallen suddenly
Into a pleurisy of faithless impudence;
A whorish itch infects thy blood; a leprosy
Of raging lust, and thou art mad to prostitute
The glory of thy virgin dower basely
For common sale. This foulness must be purged,
or thy disease will rankle to a pestilence,
Which can even taint the very air about thee:
But I shall study physic.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Learn good manners:
I take it you are saucy.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Saucy? strumpet
In thy desires: 'tis in my power to cut off
The twist thy life is spun by.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Phew, you rave now:
But if you have not perished all your reason,
Know I will use my freedom; you (Forsooth)
For change of fresh apparel, and the pocketing
Of some well looking ducats, were contented,
Passingly pleased, yes marry were you (Mark it)
To expose me to the danger now you rail at.
Brought me, nay forced me hither, without question
Of what might follow, here you find the issue:
And I distrust not but it was th' appointment
Of some succeeding fate that more concerned me
Then widowed virginity.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: You are a gallant
One of my old lord fancies. Peevish girl
Was't ever heard that youth could dote on sickness,
A grey beard, wrinkled face, a dried up marrow,
A toothless head, — a — this is but a merriment,
Merely but trial. Romanello loves thee,
Has not abundance, true, yet cannot want.
Return with me, and I will leave these fortunes,
Good maid, of gentle nature.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: By my hopes,
I never placed affection on that gentleman,
Though a deserved well; I have told him often
My resolution.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Will you hence, and trust to
My care of settling you a peace.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No surely,
