such treaty may break off.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: Off be't broken,
I'll do what thou shalt rue.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You cannot Livio.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.l: So confident? young mistress mine, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Incomparable maid.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You have been counsellor
To a strange dialogue.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: If there be constancy
In protestation of a virtuous nature;
You are secure, as the effects shall witness.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Be noble, I am credulous, my language
Hath prejudiced my heart; I and my brother
Ne'er parted at such distance; yet I glory
In the fair race he runs: but fear the violence
Of his disorder.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Little time shall quit him.

div.stage: Enter Secco leading Nitido in a garter with one hand, a rod in his other; followed by Morosa, Silvia, Floria, Clarella; Spadone behind laughing.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: The young whelp is mad, I must slice the worm out of his breech: I have noosed his neck in the collar; and I will once turn dog-leech. Stand from about me, or you'll find me terrible and furious.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Lady's good ladies, dear madam Morosa.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Honest Secco.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What was the cause? what wrong has he done to thee?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why dost thou fright us so, and art so peremptory where we are present fellow?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Honey-bird, spouse, catamountain; ah the child, the pretty poor child; the sweet faced child.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: That very word halters the earwig.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p:
Off I say, or I shall lay bare all the naked truth to your faces: his foreparts have been so lusty, and his posteriors
must do penance for't: untruss whiskin untruss; away burrs, out mare-hag moil; avaunt, thy turn comes next, avaunt thy turn comes next; avaunt the horns of my rage are advanced; hence or I shall gore ye.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Lash him soundly, let the little ape show tricks.

sp.speaker: Nie.
sp.p: Help, or I shall be throttled.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, I will help thee pretty heart, if my tongue cannot prevail; my nails shall. Barbarous minded man, let go, or I shall use my talons.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Well played dog, well played bear, sa, sa, sa; to't to't.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Fury, whore, bawd, my wife and the devil.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Tosspot, stinkard, pander, my husband and a rascal.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: Scold coxcomb, baggage, cuckold.
Crabbed age and youth
Cannot jump together:
One is like good luck,
Tother like foul weather.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let us fall in now: what uncivil rudeness
Dares offer a disturbance to this company.
Peace and delights dwell here, not brawls and outrage:
Sirrah be sure you show some reasons why
You so forget your duty? quickly show it,
Or I shall tame your choler; what's the ground on't?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Humh how's that? how's that? is he there with a wanion? Then do I begin to dwindle, — oh o, the fit, the fit; the fits upon me now, now now now.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: It shall out. First then know all Christian people Jews and infidels, he's and she's, by these presents, that I am a beast; see what I say, I say a very beast.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Go to then, a horned beast: a goodly tall horned beast in pure verity a cuckold: nay I will tickle their trangdidoes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ah thou base fellow! wouldst thou confess it and it were so: but 'tis not so, and thou liest and loudly.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Patience Morosa, you are you say a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: He justify my words; I scorn to eat 'em: this sucking ferret hath been wriggling in my old coney borough.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The boy, the babe, the infant; I spit at thee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Fie Secco fie.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Appear Spadone, my proofs are pregnant and gross: truth is the truth; I must and I will be divorced. speak Spadone and exalt thy voice.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Who I speak, alas I cannot speak I.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: As I hope to live to be a man.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Damn the prick of thy weasand pipe: where but two lie in a bed you must be bodkin bitch-baby must ye. Spadone, am I a cuckold or no cuckold?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Why? you know I an ignorant unable trifle in such business; an oaf, a simple alcatote; an innocent.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Nay nay nay, no matter for that; this Ramkin hath tupped my old rotten carrion mutton.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Rotten in thy maw, thy guts and garbage.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Spadone speak aloud what I am.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: What hast thou seen 'em doing together? doing.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are thy mad brains in thy mazzard now, thou jealous bedlam?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Didst not thou from time to time tell me as much?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Heyday, ladies and signior I am abused, they are agreed to scorn jeer and run me out of my wits; by consent this gelded hobbadehoy is a corrupted pander: the page a milk livered dildo; my wife a whore confessed; and I myself a cuckold arrant.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Truly Secco for the ancient good woman; I dare swear pointblank; and the boy surely, I ever said was to any man's thinking, a very chrisom in the thing you wot, that's my opinion clearly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What a wise goose-cap hast thou showed thyself?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p:
Here in my forehead it sticks, and stick it shall.
law I will have; I will never more tumble in sheets with thee; I will father no misbegotten of thine; the court shall trounce thee, the city cashier thee, diseases devour thee, and the spittle confound thee.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: The man has dreamed himself into a lunacy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Alas poor Nitido.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Truly I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Marry art thou, so thou art; the world says how virtuously I have carried my good name in every part about me, these threescore years and odd; and at last to slip with a child; there are men, men enough, tough and lusty (I hope) if one would give their mind to the iniquity of the flesh, but this is the life I ha' led with him a while since when 'a lies by me as cold as a dry stone.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: This only (Ladies) is a fit of novelty,
All will be reconciled, I doubt, Spadone;
Here is your hand in this howe'er denied.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Faithfully in truth forsooth.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Well, well enough — Morosa, be less troubled;
This little jar is argument of love,
It will prove lasting; beauties, I attend ye.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Youngling, a word youngling: have not you scaped the lash handsomely? thank me for't

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: I fear thy roguery, and I shall find it.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Is't possible, give me thy little fist, we are friends; have a care henceforth, remember this whilst you live. And still the urehin would, but could not do:pretty knave, and so forth: come, truce on all hands.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Beshrew your fool's head; this was jest in earnest.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I will converse with beasts; there is in mankind
No sound society, but in woman (Bless me)
Nor faith nor reason: I may justly wonder
What trust was in my mother.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A caroche, sir,
Stand at the gate.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stand let it still, and freeze there:
Make sure the socks.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Too late, you are prevented.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Brother, I come —

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Unlooked for; — I but sojourn
Myself; I keep nor house, nor entertainments,
French cooks composed, Italian collations;
Rich Persian surfeits, with a train of services,
Befitting exquisite ladies, such as you are,
Perfume not our low roofs; — the way lies open
That there. — good day, great madam.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Why d'ye slight me?
For what one act of mine, even from my childhood,
Which may deliver my deserts inferior
Or to our births or family; is nature
Become, in your contempt of me, a monster?

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: What's this Camillo!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not the strain in ordinary.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I'm out of tune to chop discourses — however,
You are a woman.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Pensive and unfortunate,
Wanting a brother's bosom to disburden
More griefs, then female weakness can keep league with;
Let worst of malice, voiced in loud report,
Spit what le dares invent against my actions;
And it shall never find a power to blemish
My mention, other than beseems a patient:
I not repine at lownesses; and the fortunes
Which I attend on now, are as I value them,
No new creation to a looser liberty:
Your strangeness only may beget a change
In wild opinion.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Here's another tang of sense, Vespucci.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Listen and observe,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Are not you pray ye, (Nay, we'll be contented
In presence of your ushers, once to prattle.
Some idle minutes) are you not enthroned
The lady regent, by whose special influence
July the count of Camerine is ordered?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: His wife 'tis known I am; and in that title,
Obedient to a service; else, of greatness
The quiet of my wish was ne'er ambitious.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: He loves you?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: As worthily, as dear.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And 'tis believed how practice quickly fashioned
A port of humorous anticness in carriage,
Discourse, demeanour, gestures.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Put home roundly.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: A ward for that blow.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Safety, of mine honour,
Instructed such deceit.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Your honour?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Witness
This brace of sprightly gallants, whose confederacy
Presumed to plot a siege.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ves. We, madam I

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: On, on,
Some leisure serves us now.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Still as lord Julio
Pursued his contract with the man (O pardon
If I forget to name him) by whose poverty
Of honest truth, I was renounced in marriage.
These two, entrusted for a secret 〈◊〉,
By tokens, letters, message, in their 〈◊〉,
Proffered their own devotions, as they 〈◊〉 them,
Almost unto an impudence; regardless
Of him, on whose supportance they 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Dare not for both your lives to interrupt her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Baited thus to vexation, I assumed
A dulness of simplicity; till afterwards
Lost to my city, freedom, and now entered
Into this present state of my condition;
(Concluding henceforth absolute security
From their lascivious villainies) I continued
My former custom of ridiculous lightness,
As they did their pursuit; t'acquaint my lord, were
T'have ruined their best certainty of living:
But that might yield suspicion in my nature;
And woman may be virtuous without mischief,
To such as tempt them.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are much to blame sirs,
Should all be truth is uttered.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: For that justice
I did command them hither, for a privacy
In conference 'twixt Flavia and her brother
Needed no secretaries such as these are:
Now Romanello, thou art every refuge
I sly for right to; if I be thy sister,
And not a bastard, answer their confession,
Or threaten vengeance, with perpetual silence.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My follies are acknowledged; you're a lady
Who have outdone example: when I trespass
In ought but duty, and respects of service,
May hopes of joys forsake me.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: To like penance
I join a constant votary.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Peace then
Is ratified, — my sister thou hast wakened
Entranced affection from its steep to knowledge
Of once more who thou art; no jealous frenzy
Shall hazard a distrust: reign in thy sweetness,
Thou only worthy woman; these two converts
Record our hearty union, I have shaken off
My thraldom, lady, and have made discoveries
of famous novels; but of those hereafter;
Thus we seal love, you shall know all and wonder.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Health and his hearts desire to Romanello;
My welcome I bring with me; noblest lady,
Excuse an ignorance of your fair presence;
This may be bold intrusion.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Not by me, sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You are not frequent here as I remember;
But since you bring your welcome with you, Livio,
Be bold to use it; to the point.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: This lady,
With both these gentlemen, in happy hour
May be partakers of the long lived amity,
Our souls must live in.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So belike the marquess
Stores some new grace, some special close employment,
For whom your kind commends by deputation
Please think on to oblige, and Livio's charity
Descends on Romanello liberally, above my means to thank.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Sienna sometimes
Has been informed how gladly there did pass
A treaty of chaste loves with Castamela;
From this good heart, it was in me an error
Wilful and causeless, 'tis confessed, that hindered
Such honourable prosecution,
Even and equal; better thoughts consider,
How much I wronged the gentle course which led ye
To vows of true affection; us of friendship.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Sits the wind there boy; leaving formal circumstance, proceed; you dally yet.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then without plea,
For countenancing what has been injurious
On my part, I am come to tender really
My sister a loved wife t'ye; freely take her
Right honest man, and as ye live together,
may your increase of years prove but one spring,
One lasting flourishing youth; she is your own,
My hands shall perfect what's required to ceremony.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Brother, this day was meant a holiday,
For feast on every side.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The new-turned courtier
Proffers most frankly; but withal leaves out
A due consideration of the narrowness
Our short estate is bounded in, some politics
As they rise up (Like Livio) to perfection
In their own competencies, gather also
Grave supplement of providence and wisdom;
Yet he abates in his — you use a triumph
In your advantages, it smells of state:
We know you are no fool.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sooth I believe him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Else 'twere imposture.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: Folly rank, and sense less.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Enjoin an oath at large.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Since you mean earnest,
Receive in satisfaction; I am resolved
For single life; there was a time (Was Livio)
When indiscretion blinded forecast in me;
But recollection, with your rules of thriftiness,
Prevailed against all passion.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You'd be courted,
Courtship's the child of coyness Romanello;
And for the rules 'tis possible to name them.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: A single life's no burden; but to draw
In yokes is chargeable, and doth require
A double maintenance; Livio's very words,
For he can live without a wife and purchase,
By'r lady so you do sir, send you joy on't;
These rules you see are possible, and answered.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Full, — answer was late mate to this already,
My sister's only thine.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Where lives the creature
Your pity stoops to pin upon your servant?
Not in a nunnery for a year's probation?
Fie on such coldness, there are bowrds of fancies
Ravished from troops of fairy nymphs, and virgins
Culled from the downy breasts of Queens their mothers,
In the Titanian empire, far from mortals:
But these are tales; troth I have quite abandoned
All loving humour.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Here is scorn in riddles,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Were there another marquess in Sienna
More potent than the same who is vicegerent
To the great Duke of Florence, our grand master:
Were the great Duke himself here, and would lift up
My head to fellow pomp amongst his nobles,
By falsehood to the honour of a sister,
Urging me instrument in his seraglio;
I'd tear the wardrobe of an outside from him
Rather than live a pandar to his bribery.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So would the he you talk to, Romanello,
Without a noise that's singular.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: She's a countess
Flavia, she; but she has an Earl her husband,
Though far from our procurement.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Castamela
Is refused then.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Never designed my choice,
You know and I know (Livio) more I tell thee,
A noble honesty ought to give allowance,
When reason intercedes; by all that's manly,
I range not in derision but compassion.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Intelligence flies swiftly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Pretty swiftly;
We have compared the copy with the original,
And find no disagreement.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So my sister
can be no wife for Romanello?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No, no,
One no once more and ever; — this your courtesy
Foiled me a second; — sir, you brought a welcome,
You must not part without it; scan with pity
My plainness, I intend nor gall, nor quarrel.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Far be't from me to press a blame, great lady;
I kiss your noble hands, and to these gentlemen
Present a civil parting; Romanello,
By the next foot-post thou wilt hear some news
Of alteration; if I send, come to me.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Questionless, yea.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: My thanks may quit the favour.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Brother his intercourse of conference,
Appears at once perplexed, but withal sensible.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Doubts easily resolved; upon your virtues
The whole foundation of my peace is grounded:
I'll guard ye to your home, lost in one comfort
Here I have found another.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Goodness prosper it.

div.head: Act. v.
div.stage: Enter Octavio, Troylo, Secco, and Nitido.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No more of these complaints and clamours;
Have we nor enemies abroad,
Nor waking sycophants,
Who peering through our actions, wait occasion
By which they watch to lay advantage open
To vulgar descant, but amongst ourselves
Some whom we call our own must practise scandal
(Out of a liberty of ease and fullness)
Against our honour, we shall quickly order
Strange reformation sirs, and you will find it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: When servants servants, slaves, once relish licence
Of good opinion from a noble nature,
They take upon them boldness to abuse
Such interest, and lord it o'er their fellows,
As if they were exempt from that condition.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: He is unfit to manage public matters
Who knows not how to rule at home his household;
You must be jealous (Puppy) of a boy too;
Raise uproars, (Bandy noise) amongst young maidens;
Keep revels in your madness, use authority
Of giving punishment; a fool must fool ye;
And this is all but pastime, as you think it.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: With your good lordship's favour, since, Spadone
Confessed it was a gullery put on Secco,
For some revenge meant me.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: He vowed it truth
Before the ladies in my hearing.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sirrah,
I'll turn you to your shop again and trinkets,
Your suds and pan of small-coal; take your damsel
The grand old rag, of beauty; your death's head;
Try then what custom reverence can trade in;
Fiddle, and play your pranks amongst your neighbours;
That all the town may roar ye; now ye simper
And look like a shaved skull.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.l: This comes of prating.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: I am my lord a worm, pray my lord tread on
Me, I will not turn again; alas I shall never venture
To hang my pole out; on my knees I begs it,
My bare knees, I will down unto my wife
And do what she will have me, all I can do;
Nay more, (If she will have it) ask forgiveness,
Be an obedient husband; never cross her,
Unless sometimes in kindness: signior Troylo,
Speak one sweet word; I'll swear 'twas in my madness,
I said I knew not what, and that no creature
was brought by you amongst the ladies, Nitido
I'll forswear thee too.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Wait a while our pleasure;
You shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.l: Remember me now.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Troylo, thou art my brother's son, and nearest
In blood to me; thou hast been next in counsels.
Those ties of nature (If thou canst consider
How much they do engage) work by instinct
In every worthy or ignoble mention
Which can concern me.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sir, they have and shall
As long as I bear life.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Henceforth the stewardship
My carefulness, for the honour of our family
Has undertook, must yield the world account,
And make clear reckonings; yet we stand suspected
In our even courses.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: But when time shall wonder
How much it was mistaken in the issue
Of honourable, and secure contrivements.
Your wisdom crowned with laurels of a justice
Deserving approbation will quite foil
The ignorance of popular opinion.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Report is merry with my feats; my dotage
Undoubtedly the vulgar voice doth carol it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: True sir, but Romanello's late admission
Warrants that giddy confidence of rumor
Without all contradiction; now 'tis oracle,
And so received; I am confirmed, the lady
By this time proves his scorn as well as laughter.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: And we with her his tabletalk — she stands not
In any firm affection to him.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: None sir,
More than her wonted nobleness afforded
Out of a civil custom.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: We are resolute
In our determination, meaning quickly
To cause these clouds fly off; the ordering of it
Nephew is thine.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Your care and love commands me.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I come, my lord, a suitor.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Honest Livio,
Perfectly honest, really; no fallacies
No flaws are in thy truth: I shall promote thee
To place more eminent.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Livio deserves it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What suit? speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pray discharge my office,
My mastership; 'twere better live a yeoman
And live with men, then over-eye your houses,
Whiles I myself am ridden like a jade.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Such breath sounds but ill manners; know young man,
Old as we are, our soul retains a fire
Active and quick in motion, which shall equal
The daringest boys ambition of true manhood
That wears a pride to brave us.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: He is my friend, sir.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You are weary of our service, and may leave it.
We can court no man's duty.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Without passion,
My lord, d'ye think your nephew here, your Troylo
Parts in your spirit as freely as your blood;
'Tis no rude question.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Had you known his mother
You might have sworn her honest; let him justify
Himself not base born: for thy sister's sake
I do conceive the like of thee; be wiser,
But prate to me no more thus; — if the gallant
Resolve on my attendance, ere he leave me,
Acquaint him with the present service, nephew,
I meant to employ him in.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fie Livio, wherefore
Turned wild upon the sudden.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pretty gentleman,
How modestly you move your doubts? how tamely?
Ask Romanello, he hath without leave
Surveyed your bowers of fancies, hath discovered
The mystery of those pure nuns; those chaste ones,
Untouched forsooth; the holy academy:
Hath found a mother's daughter there of mine too,
And one who called my father father, talks out,
Ruffles in mirth on't; baffled to my face
The glory of her greatness by it.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Truly.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Death to my sufferance, canst thou hear this misery,
And answer't with a truly? 'twas thy wickedness
False as thine own heart tempted my credulity,
That, her to ruin; she was once an innocent,
As free from spot, as the blue face of heaven
Without a cloud in't; she is now as sullied
As is that canopy, when mists and vapours
Divide it from our sight, and threaten pestilence.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Says he so, Livio.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes, an't like your nobleness;
He truly does so say; your breach of friendship
With me, must borrow courage from your uncle,
Whiles your sword talks an answer; there's no remedy,
I will have satisfaction, though thy life
Come short of such demand.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Then satisfaction
Much worthier than your sword can force, you shall have,
Yet mine shall keep the peace; I can be angry
And brave aloud in my reply; but honour
Schools me to fitter grounds, this as a gentleman
I promise ere the minutes of the night
Warn us to rest, such satisfaction (Hear me
and credit it) as more you cannot wish for,
So much not think of.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Not? the time is short,
Before our sleeping hour: you vow.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I do,
Before we ought to sleep.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So I intend to,
On confidence of which, what left the marquessa
In charge for me? I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Invite count Julio
His lady, and her brother, with their company
To my lords court at supper.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Easy business,
And then. —

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And then soon after, the performance
Of my past vow waits on ye, but be certain
You bring them with ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yet your servant.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Nearer my friend, you'll find no less.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, is't possible.

div.stage: Enter Castamela, Clarella, Floria, and Silvia.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You have discoursed to me a lovely story,
My heart doth dance toth' music; 'twere a sin
Should I in any tittle stand distrustful
Where such a people such as you are, innocent
Even by the patent of your years and language,
Inform a truth; oh talk it o'er again;
Ye are ye say three daughters of one mother,
That mother only sister to the marquess,
Whose charge hath since her death (Being left a widow)
Here in this place preferred your education:
Is't so?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is even so, and howsoever
Report may wander loosely in some scandal
Against our privacies; yet we have wanted
No graceful means fit for our births and qualities,
to train us up into a virtuous knowledge
Of what, and who we ought to be.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Our uncle
Hath often told us, how it more concerned him
Before he showed us to the world, to render
Our youths and our demeanours in each action
Approved by his experience, then too early
Adventure on the follies of the age,
By prone temptations fatal.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: In good deed la,
We mean no harm.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Deceit must want a shelter
Under a roof, that's covering to souls
So white as breathes beneath it, such as these are;
My happiness shares largely in this blessing,
And I must thank direction of the providence
Which led me hither.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Aptly have you styled it,
A providence for ever in chaste loves,
Such majesty hath power, — our kinsman Troylo
Was herein his own factor; he will prove,
Believe him lady, every way as constant,
As noble, we can bail him from the cruelty
Of misconstruction.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You will find his tongue
But a just secretary to his heart.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: The guardianess
(Dear creatures) now and then, it seems
Makes bold to talk.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sh'as waited on us
From all our cradles, will prate sometimes oddly,
However means but sport; I am unwilling
Our household should break up, but must obey
His wisdom, under whose command we live:
Sever our companies I'm sure we shall not;
Yet 'tis a pretty life this and a quiet.

div.stage: Enter Morosa, Secco, his apron on, basin of water, scissors, comb, towels, razor, etc.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Chuck, duckling, honey, mouse, monkey all and every thing; I am thine ever and only, will never offend again, as I hope to shave clean and get honour by't, heartily I ask forgiveness; be gracious to thine own flesh and blood, and kiss me home.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Look you provoke us no more, for this time you shall find mercy; — was't that hedgehog set thy brains a crowing? be quits with him, but do not hurt the great male-baby.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Enough, I am wise, and will be merry, — haste beauties, the caroches will sudden receive ye; a night of pleasure is towards, pray for good husbands a piece, that may trim you featly, (Dainty ones) and let me alone to trim them.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Loving hearts be quick as soon as ye can, time runs apace; what you must do, do nimbly, and give your minds to't; young bloods stand fumbling? fie away, be ready for shame beforehand; husband, stand to thy tackling husband, like a man of mettle: go, go, go.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Will ye come away loiterers? shall I wait all day? Am I at livery d'ye think.

div.stage: Enter Spadone ready to be trimmed, and Nitido.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Here and ready; what a mouthing thou keepest, I have but scoured my hands, and curried my head to save time, honest Secco, neat Secco, precious barbarian, now thou lookest like a worshipful tooth-drawer, would I might see thee on horseback, in the pomp once.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: A chair, a chair, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Here's a chair, a chair politic, my fine boy, sit thee down in triumph, and rise one of the nine worthies; thou'lt be a sweet youth anon sirrah.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
So, to work with a grace now, I cannot but highly be in love with the fashion of gentry, which is never
complete, till the snipsnap of dexterity, hath mowed off the excrements of slovenry.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Very commodiously delivered I protest.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Nay, the thing under your fingers is a whelp of the wits I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I a whelp of the wits? no, no, I cannot bark impudently, and ignorantly enough; — o, and a man of this art had now and then sovereignty over fair ladies, you would tickle their upper and their lower lips, you'd so smooch and belaver their chops.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: We light on some offices for ladies too, as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Yes, frizzle or powder their hair, plane their eyebrows, set a nap on their cheeks, keep secrets, and tell news; that's all.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Wink fast with both your eyes, the ingredients to the composition of this ball, are most odorous camphire, pure soap of Venice, oil of sweet almonds, with the spirit of Allome; they will search and smart shrewdly, if you keep not the shop-windows of your head close.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: News? well remembered, that's part of your trade too (Prithee do not rub so roughly) and how goes the tattle oth' town? what novelties stirring, ha?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Strange, and scarce to be credited; a gelding was lately seen to leap an old mare; and an old man of one hundred and twelve stood in a white sheet for getting a wench of fifteen with child, here hard by, most admirable and portentous.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I'll never believe it, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Most certain, some doctor farriers are of opinion that the mare may cast a foal, which the master of their hall conclude in spite of all jockeys and their familiars, will carry every race before him, without spur or switch.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p:
O rare, a man might venture ten or twenty to one safely then, and ne'er be in danger of the cheat; — this
water methinks is none of the sweetest; camphire and soap of Venice say ye.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: With a little grecum album for mundification.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Grecum album is a kind of white presumed powder, which plain country people, I believe, call dog-musk.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Dog-musk, pox o'the dog-musk, what dost mean to bleach my nose, thou givest such twitches to't? set me at liberty as soon as thou canst, gentle Secco

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Only pare off a little superfluous down from your chin, and all's done.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Pish, no matter for that; dispatch, I entreat thee.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Have patience man, 'tis for his credit to be neat.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: What's that so cold at my throat; and scrubs so hard?

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: A kind of steel instrument yclept a razor, a sharp tool and a keen, it has a certain virtue of cutting a throat, if a man please to give his mind to't; — hold up your muzzle signior, — when did you talk bawdily to my wife last? tell me for your own good (Signior) I advise you.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I talk bawdily to thy wife? hang bawdry; good now mind thy business, lest thy hand slip.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Give him kind words you were best, for a toy that I know.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Confess, or I shall mar your grace in whiffing tobacco or squirting of sweet wines down your gullet; — you have been offering to play the gelding we told ye of I suppose; — speak truth, (Move the semicircle of your countenance to my left hand file) out with the truth; would you have had a leap.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Spadone, thou art in a lamentable pickle, have a good heart and pray if thou canst, I pity thee.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: I protest and vow friend Secco, I know no leaps, I.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Let goatish and an eunuch? this cut, and then —

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: Confound thee, thy leaps and thy cuts, I am no eunuch, you finical ass, I am no eunuch; but at all points as well provided, as any he in Italy, and that thy wife could have told thee: this your conspiracy, to thrust my head into a brazen tub of kitchen-sea, hoodwink mine eyes in mud-soap, and then offer to cut my throat in the dark like a coward? I may live to be revenged on both of ye.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: O scurvy! thou art angry, feel man whether thy weasand be not cracked first.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: You must fiddle my brains into a jealousy, rub my temples with saffron, and burnish my forehead with the juice of yellows: have I fitted ye now sir?

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: All's whole yet I hope?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, sirrah; all is whole yet; but if ever thou dost speak treason against my sweeting and me once more, thoul't find a roguy bargain on't; dear, this was handled like one of spirit and discretion: Nitido has paged it trimly too; no wording, but make ready and attend at court.

sp.speaker: Sec.
sp.p: Now we know thou art a man; we forget what hath passed, and are fellows and friends again.

sp.speaker: Nit.
sp.p: Wipe your face clean; and take heed of a razor.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: The fear put me into a sweat; I cannot help it; I am glad I have my throat mine own, and must laugh for company, or be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You find sir, I have proved a ready servant,
And brought th'expected guests, amid these feastings,
These costly entertainments; you must pardon
My incivility that here sequesters
Your ears from choice of music, or discourse
To a less pleasant parley; night draws on,
And quickly will grow old; it were unmanly
For any gentleman, who loves his honour,
to put it on the rack; here is small comfort
Of such a satisfaction as was promised,
Though certainly it must be had; pray tell me
What can appear about me to be used thus?
My soul is free from injuries.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: My tongue from serious untruths, I never wronged you,
Love you too well to mean it now.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Not wronged me?
(Blessed heaven!) this is the bandy of a patience
Beyond all sufferance.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: If your own acknowledgement
Quit me not fairly ere the hours of rest
Shall shut our eyes up, say I made a forfeit
Of what no length of years can once redeem.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Fine whirls in tame imagination; on sir,
It is scarce mannerly at such a season,
Such a solemnity (The place and presence
Considered) with delights, to mix combustions.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Prepare for free contents, and give 'em welcome.

div.stage: Flourish. Enter Octavio, Julio, Flavia, Romanello, Camillo and vespuoi.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I dare not study words, or hold a compliment
For this particular; this special favour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your bounty and your love, my lord, must justly
Engage a thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Indeed
Varieties of entertainment here
Have so exceeded all account of plenty,
That you have left (Great sir) no rarities
Except an equal welcome which may purchase
Opinion of a common hospitality.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: But for this grace (Madam) I will lay open
Before your judgements which I know can rate 'em
A cabinet of jewels, rich and lively,
The world can show none goodlier; those I prize
Dear as my life — nephew —

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sir, I obey you. —

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Jewels, my lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No strangers eye ere viewed them,
Unless your brother Romanello haply
Was would unto a sight for his approvement:
No more.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not I, I do protest; I hope sir
You cannot think I am a lapidary;
I skill in jewels?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: 'Tis a proper quality
For any gentleman; your other friends
May be are not so coy.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Who they, they know not
A topaz from an opal.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: We are ignorant
In gems which are not common.

sp.speaker: Ves.
sp.l: But his lordship
Is pleased (It seems) to try our ignorance.
For passage of the time, till they are brought,
Pray look upon a letter lately sent me,
Lord Julio, (Madam) Romanello, read
A novelty; 'tis written from Bonony
Fabricio once a merchant in this city
Is entered into orders, and received
Amongst the Capuchins a fellow, news
Which ought not any way to be unpleasant,
Certain I can assure it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He at last has
Bestowed himself upon a glorious service.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Most happy man, I now forgive the injuries
Thy former life exposed thee to.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Turn Capuchin,
He, whiles I stand a cypher and fill up
Only an useless sum to be laid out
In an unthrifty lewdness, that must buy
Both name and riot; o my fickle destiny!

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Sister, you cannot taste this course but bravely,
But thankfully.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: He's now dead to the world
And lives to heaven, a saint's reward him;
My only loved lord, all your fears are henceforth
Confined unto a sweet and happy penance.

div.stage: Enter Troylo, Castamela, Clarella, Floria, Silvia, and Morosa.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Behold, I keep my word, these are the jewels
Deserve a treasury; I can be prodigal
Amongst my friends; examine well their lustre
Does it not sparkle? wherefore dwells your silence
In such amazement?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Patience keep within me,
Leap not yet rudely into scorn of anger.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Beauty's incomparable.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Romanello,
I have been only steward to your pleasures;
You loved this lady once, what say you now to her?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I must not court you sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: By no means fair one,
Enjoy your life of greatness; sure the spring
Is past, the bowers of fancies is quite withered
And offered like a lottery to be drawn;
I dare not venture for a blank, excuse me, —
Exquisite jewels.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Hark ye Troylo.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Spare me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You then renounce all right in Castamela,
Say Romanello.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Gladly.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Then I must not;
Thus I embrace mine own, my wife; confirm it.
Thus when I fail (My dearest) to deserve thee
Comforts and life shall fail me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Like vow I, for my part.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Livio, now my brother, justly
I have given satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O excuse
Our secrecy, I have been —

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Much more worthy
A better brother, he a better friend
Than my dull brains could fashion.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Am I cozened.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You are not Romanello; we examined
On what conditions your affections fixed,
And found them merely courtship; but my nephew
Loved with a faith resolved, and used his policy
To draw the lady into this society,
More freely to discover his sincerity
Even without Livio's knowledge, thus succeeded
And prospered, he's my heir and she deserved him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Storm not at what is passed.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: A fate as happy
May crown you with a full content.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Whatever
Report hath talked of me abroad, and these
Know they are all my nieces, are the daughters
To my dead only sister, this their guardianess
Since they first saw the world; indeed my mistresses
They are, I have none other; how brought up
Their qualities may speak; now Romanello,
And gentlemen, for such I know ye all,
Portions they shall not want both sit and worthy;
Nor will I look on fortune, if you like
Court them and win them, here is free access,
In mine own court henceforth; only for thee

sp.speaker: Livio
sp.l: I wish Clarella were allotted.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Most noble lord, I am struck silent.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Brother, here's noble choice.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Frenzy, how didst thou seize me!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We knew you sir, in Prugniolo's posture.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Were merry at the sight.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.l: And gave you welcome.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Indeed forsooth, and so we did an't like ye.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Enough, enough; now to shut up the night,
Some menial servants of mine own are ready
For to present a merriment; they intend
According to th'occasion of the meeting,
In several shapes to show how love o'ersways
All men of several conditions; soldier,
Gentry, fool, scholar, merchant man, and clown:
A harmless recreation; take your places. —
Your duties are performed henceforth, Spadone,
Cast off thy borrowed title: nephew Troylo,
His mother gave thee suck; esteem him honestly.
Lights for the lodgings, 'tis high time for rest;
Great men may be mistook when they mean best.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: A while suspected (Gentlemen) I look
For no new law, being quit by the book.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Our harmless pleasures, free in every sort
Actions of scandal; may they free report.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Distrust is base, presumption urgeth wrongs;
But noble thoughts must prompt as noble tongues.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Fancy and judgement are a play's full matter:
If we have erred in one, right you the latter.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
